fields.headline: Aftermath of mixed fortunes
fields.bodyText: The sun umbrellas are back up in many destinations that were hit, but for the worst-affected areas recovery could be months or even years away. Remember that if the Foreign Office advises against travel to a particular region, your travel insurance may be invalid. Check with your insurer. Sri Lanka The Foreign Office advises against all but essential travel to affected areas along the eastern and southern coasts, and to the south-western coast south of Kalutara, until local conditions improve. There is extensive damage to buildings and infrastructure and risk of disease. If you visit an affected area, ensure your inoculations are up to date, drink only bottled water, and avoid possibly contaminated seafood. The tourist board says most tourist destinations have been unaffected and are ready to welcome visitors, including west coast beaches, all historical sites and the hill country. Tour operators are cancelling or postponing holidays to the affected areas in the south until the end of January at least. A list of affected hotels can be found on the Sri Lanka Tourist Board website (www.contactsrilanka.org Thailand The Foreign Office continues to warn against all but essential travel to affected resorts and towns along Thailand's west coast, particularly Phuket, Krabi, Phangnga, Phi Phi and Khao Lak where the infrastructure and public services are severely disrupted. Phuket Airport is open and 80 per cent of hotels are said to be operating normally though the Andaman coast of the island is badly damaged. Check which hotels have reopened on www.sawadee.com In Krabi 90 per cent of hotels are operational. Maldives The majority of islands in the Maldives escaped significant damage and most tour operators have resumed travel to the islands. At the time of going to press, only 19 out of 83 hotels were still closed. Trailfinders said most of its hotels had reopened, though a handful would not reopen until the end of March. MyTravel has resumed travel to almost all of the 55 resorts it uses and all but a handful of Thomson's featured hotels have reopened. Health consultants working with the Federation of Tour Operators are assessing structural integrity of buildings, and making sure sufficient food and drinks are available before hotels reopen. Check which hotels are up and running on the website www.visitmaldives.com Indonesia The Foreign Office continues to advise against all travel to the Aceh province on the island of Sumatra, where the west and north coasts were hit causing widespread flooding and damage. Bali was not affected. It continues to advise against all travel to the Maluku and Sulawesi provinces due to a risk of violence towards westerners. There is deemed to be a high risk of terrorism throughout the country. In affected areas there has been considerable damage to health services and there is a high risk of disease. Visitors should drink only bottled water. A spokeswoman from STA travel said anyone due to fly to Sumatra would be offered alternative destinations, postponements and refunds during January, but asked those due to travel to contact their airline to check details. Other countries India: The Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh coasts, plus the Andaman and Nicobar Islands were worst-affected, with extensive damage to buildings and other infrastructure and a risk of disease. The southern tip of Kerala sustained minor damage. The Foreign Office is not advising against travel. Check with your travel company that it is safe to go. Seychelles: There is some incidental damage, compounded by flooding and landslides caused by heavy rain, and damage to roads and bridges. Three hotels, in Praslin, have closed temporarily: Paradise Sun, La Reserve and Vacanze Cote d'Or Lodge. More information from the Foreign Office (0870 606 0290; www.fco.gov.uk and the Department of Health (www.dh.gov.uk
